paragraphs.title: Title cell
paragraphs.text:
%md

Script for loading up data sets from csv into parquet format with partitioning, bucketting and sorting by source ID

TODOs:
* decide on the final location for the ingested datasets

msg.data:
Script for loading up data sets from csv into parquet format with partitioning, bucketting and sorting by source ID

TODOs:
* decide on the final location for the ingested datasets
* re-ingest PS1 using updated schema

paragraphs.title: Define structure types for the data sets to be loaded
paragraphs.text:

paragraphs.title: Convenience function definitions
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

# useful definitions

# number of buckets for our platform
NUM_BUCKETS = 2048

# the following based on example code kindly supplied by Enrique Utrilla:

# Save a dataframe to a set of bucketed parquet files, repartitioning beforehand and sorting by source UID within the buckets:
def saveToBinnedParquet(df, outputParquetPath, name, mode = "error", nBuckets = NUM_BUCKETS):
    df = df.repartition(nBuckets, "source_id")
    df.write.format("parquet") \
            .mode(mode) \
            .bucketBy(nBuckets, "source_id") \
            .sortBy("source_id") \
            .option("path", outputParquetPath) \
            .saveAsTable(name)

# and to re-establish the resource in a new (or reset) spark context:
def reattachParquetFileResourceToSparkContext(table_name, file_path, *schema_structures):
    """
    Creates a Spark (in-memory) meta-record for the table resource specified for querying 
    through the PySpark SQL API.
    
    Assumes that the table contains the Gaia source_id attribute and that the files have 
    been previously partitioned, bucketed and sorted on this field in parquet format
    - see function saveToBinnedParquet().  If the table name specified already exists in the
    catalogue IT WILL BE REMOVED (but the underlying data, assumed external, will remain).
    
    Parameters
    ----------
    table_name : str
        The table name to be used as the identifier in SQL queries etc.
    file_path : str
        The full disk file system path name to the folder containing the parquet file set. 
    schema_structures : StructType
        One or more schema structures expressed as a StructType object containing a list of
        StructField(field_name : str, type : data_type : DataType(), nullable : boolean)
    """

    # put in the columns and their data types ...
    table_create_statement = "CREATE TABLE `" + table_name + "` ("
    for schema_structure in schema_structures:
        for field in schema_structure:
            table_create_statement += "`" + field.name + "` " + field.dataType.simpleString() + ","
    # ... zapping that extraneous comma at the end
    table_create_statement = table_create_statement[:-1]
        
    # append the organisational details 
    table_create_statement += ") USING parquet OPTIONS (path '" + file_path + "') "
    table_create_statement += "CLUSTERED BY (source_id) SORTED BY (source_id) INTO %d"%(NUM_BUCKETS) + " BUCKETS"
    
    # sanity check
    print(table_create_statement)
    
    # scrub any existing record - N.B. tables defined in this way are EXTERNAL, so this statement will not scrub
    # the underlying file data set. Also if the table doesn't exist, this will silently do nothing (no exception
    # will be thrown).
    spark.sql("DROP TABLE IF EXISTS " + table_name)
    
    # create the table resource
    spark.sql(table_create_statement)

paragraphs.title: Join, bucket, partition and write 2MASS PSC
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

# 2MASS best neighbours
tmassxm_df = sqlContext.read.option('mode','failfast').option('header', 'true').schema(tmasspscxsc_best_neighbour_schema).csv('file:////user/nch/CSV/2MASS_BEST_NEIGHBOURS/*csv')

# from original csv:
tmass_df = sqlContext.read.option('mode','failfast').option('header', 'false').option('delimiter','|').option('nullValue','\\N').schema(twomass_psc_schema).csv('file:////user/nch/CSV/2MASS/psc_*')
# trim leading/trailing spaces in the designation ID string since the DPAC neighbour tables do so (apparently):
from pyspark.sql.functions import trim
tmass_df = tmass_df.withColumn("designation", trim(tmass_df.designation))

# join up on the external catalogue identifier
combo_df = tmassxm_df.join(tmass_df, tmassxm_df.original_ext_source_id == tmass_df.designation)
# N.B. let's stick to an inner join. Could do a right-outer join to preserve unmatched external catalogue records, but the resulting table would need
#      to be used with extreme care since it will contain duplicates (the same external catalogue source can be the best match to more than one Gaia source).

# save it to hdfs://master01:9000/partitioned/
saveToBinnedParquet(combo_df, 'hdfs://master01:9000/hdfs/partitioned/GEDR3_2MASSPSC_BEST_NEIGHBOURS', name = 'gaia_source_tmasspsc_best_neighbours', mode = 'overwrite')

# Full monty to HDFS: Took 50 min 8 sec. Last updated by nch at March 29 2021, 11:15:01 AM.

#allwise_df.drop('spare')
# 2nd try: read from parquet, renaming source_id -> src_id to try to squeeze into existing scratch space. If probs, move stuff off hdfs to cephfs to clear some breathing space:
# e.g. hadoop fs get hdfs:///c,,... cephfs
allwise_df = sqlContext.read.parquet('file:////user/nch/PARQUET/TESTS/ALLWISE/*.parquet').withColumnRenamed("source_id", "src_id")

# join up on the external catalogue identifier N.B. ALLWISE column source_id must be renamed to src_id (see schema definition cell at start of this notebook) to avoid name clash.
combo_df = allwisexm_df.join(allwise_df, allwisexm_df.original_ext_source_id == allwise_df.designation)

# save it to hdfs://master01:9000/partitioned/
saveToBinnedParquet(combo_df, 'hdfs://master01:9000/hdfs/partitioned/GEDR3_ALLWISE_BEST_NEIGHBOURS', name = 'gaia_source_allwise_best_neighbours', mode = 'overwrite')
